required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Post Intravitreal Injection Topical NSAID vs. Patching
clinical_study.official_title: Pain Control Following Intravitreal Injection Using Topical Nepefanac 0.3% or Pressure Patching: A Prospective, Randomized, Placebo Controlled Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary

clinical_study.source: The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary

brief_summary.textblock: A prospective randomized trial, to evaluate post-injection comfort measures comparing topical NSAID (nepafenac 0.3% suspension) and patching.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a single masked, randomized, placebo-controlled study that will enroll approximately 60 subjects with recent active retina related disease requiring intravitreal agents. Subjects will be randomized into one of 3 groups in a 1:1:1 ratio, and assigned to receive nepafenac 0.3% suspension or a sham procedure. Subjects will have a one in three (33%) chance of receiving active treatment (no sham procedure), a one in three (33%) chance of receiving patching procedure (no active treatment) or a one in three (33%) chance of receiving placebo (no active treatment).
Study participants will then complete the Visual Analog Scale immediately following injection and then after 1 hour, and, 24 hours. The VAS data along with relevant data related to each subject's injection will also be compiled, including, but not limited to: drug injected, diagnosis, co-morbid conditions, history of previous injections, visual acuity, age, and gender.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Group 1: Placebo (Preservative free artificial tears) Group 2: Nepefanac 0.3% suspension Group 3: Patch for 2 hours

primary_outcome.measure: Post Intravitreal Injection Measurement of Pain
primary_outcome.time_frame: 6 hours and 24 hours after intravitreal injection
primary_outcome.description: Change from Baseline post intravitreal injection pain at 6 and 24 hours as measured by the Numeric Pain Rating Scale. The pain numeric rating scale (NRS), on which patients rate their current pain intensity from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain"), at the screening, 6 hours and 24 hours.

arm_group.arm_group_label: A single drop of nepafenac 0.3% suspension
arm_group.description: A single drop of nepafenac 0.3% suspension (Ilevro; Alcon, Fort Worth, TX)
A light pressure patch applied for two hours

arm_group.arm_group_label: A single drop of preservative-free Artificial Tears
arm_group.description: A single drop of preservative-free Theratears tear drop, (Akron, Ann Arbor, MI).

intervention.intervention_name: nepafenac 0.3% suspension (Ilevro; Alcon, Fort Worth, TX)
intervention.arm_group_label: A single drop of nepafenac 0.3% suspension

intervention.intervention_name: Theratears tear drop, (Akron, Ann 111 Arbor, MI)
intervention.arm_group_label: A single drop of preservative-free Artificial Tears

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age or older
- Already scheduled for anti-VEGF injection based on standard of care for disease process.
- Ability to provide written informed consent
- Capable of complying with study protocol.
- Volunteer written informed consent with the understanding that consent may be withdrawn by the subject at any time without prejudice to future care
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of past intraocular injection of steroid medication.
- Experiencing baseline eye pain
- Monocular; non-study eye with VA<20/100.
- Unwilling or unable to follow or comply with all study related procedures

facility.name: New York Eye and Ear Infirmary

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary
